density.note: 3% salt increases density by ~2.1% compared to pure water

specificHeat.note: Lower than pure water (~4.186 J/g°C); dissolved ions reduce specific heat

thermalConductivity.note: Slightly higher than pure water; salt ions conduct heat

latentHeatOfVaporization.note: Higher than pure water (~2257 kJ/kg); dissolved salt requires more energy to vaporize

compressibility.note: Slightly less compressible than pure water due to dissolved ions

antoineCoefficients.source: Based on pure water coefficients from NIST Chemistry WebBook (Bridgeman and Aldrich, 1964). Boiling point elevation (declared as 0.515°C in info.json) is calculated using the van't Hoff factor for electrolytes: ΔTb = i·Kb·m = 1.9 × 0.512 °C/m × 0.5291 m ≈ 0.5147°C. Precise NaCl molar mass: 58.443 g/mol
antoineCoefficients.note: Uses pure water's experimentally-verified Antoine equation. Salt lowers vapor pressure (Raoult's Law) and increases boiling point via colligative property (van't Hoff factor i=1.9 for NaCl). Boiling point at sea level: 100.515°C (100°C water + 0.515°C elevation from dissolved salt).

ionicStrength.note: Na⁺ and Cl⁻ each contribute; used in advanced activity coefficient models

electricalConductivity.note: 3% NaCl makes water an electrolyte. Pure water: ~0.0005 S/m. Salt dissociates into conducting ions (Na⁺ and Cl⁻).
electricalConductivity.applicationUse: Sensors, electrolysis simulations, conductivity probes, safety (risk of electrical hazards). 10,000x more conductive than pure water!

vanThoffFactor.formula: i = number of particles per solute molecule
vanThoffFactor.note: NaCl ideally dissociates into 2 ions (Na⁺ + Cl⁻), but real solutions show i=1.9 due to ion-pairing and electrostatic effects.
vanThoffFactor.applicationUse: Calculate colligative properties: ΔTb = i × Kb × m (boiling point elevation), ΔTf = i × Kf × m (freezing point depression), osmotic pressure = i × M × R × T

saturationPoint.note: Maximum concentration of NaCl that can dissolve in water at 25°C. Beyond this, crystals precipitate.
saturationPoint.applicationUse: If player evaporates water or adds more salt, track when crystallization begins. Spawn NaCl(s) at bottom of container when saturation is exceeded.
